canonical_explanation.text:
Biotechnology has wide-ranging applications in agriculture, medicine, and diagnostics. In agriculture, genetically modified organisms (GMOs) have been developed for pest resistance, herbicide tolerance, and improved nutritional quality. Bt crops (e.g., Bt cotton) contain genes from Bacillus thuringiensis that encode Cry proteins (crystal proteins) toxic to specific insect pests. Cry1Ac and Cry2Ab are effective against cotton bollworms, while Cry1Ab is used against corn borers. The Cry proteins exist as inactive protoxins in the bacterium and are activated in the alkaline gut of insect larvae, forming pores in the midgut epithelium and causing cell lysis and death. Transgenic animals are animals whose genome has been altered by introducing foreign genes; they are used for studying gene regulation, as models for human diseases, and for producing biological products.

In medicine, recombinant DNA technology has enabled the production of human insulin (humulin) in E. coli, gene therapy for genetic disorders (ADA deficiency treated by introducing functional ADA gene into lymphocytes ex vivo), and molecular diagnostics using ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay) and PCR. ELISA uses antigen-antibody interaction to detect pathogens, while PCR amplifies trace amounts of pathogenic DNA for early diagnosis. Biosafety concerns regarding GMOs have led to regulatory frameworks. The Genetic Engineering Approval Committee (GEAC) in India regulates the research and release of GMOs. Bioethics addresses moral questions surrounding genetic manipulation. Biopiracy refers to the unauthorised use of bio-resources and traditional knowledge by multinational companies, with notable cases involving neem, turmeric, and basmati rice patents.
rules: Bt crops contain cry genes from Bacillus thuringiensis encoding Cry proteins (crystal proteins) toxic to specific insect pests
Cry1Ac and Cry2Ab control cotton bollworms; Cry1Ab controls corn borers — different Cry proteins target different insect orders
Cry proteins are inactive protoxins that are activated in the alkaline gut of insect larvae, creating pores in midgut epithelium
Transgenic animals have altered genomes and are used for studying gene regulation, disease models, vaccine testing, and product production
Human insulin (humulin) is produced in E. coli using rDNA technology — proinsulin is expressed and processed into A and B chains
Gene therapy for ADA deficiency: functional ADA gene is introduced into patient's lymphocytes ex vivo, which are returned to the patient
ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay) detects pathogens using antigen-antibody interaction with enzyme-linked colour change
PCR-based molecular diagnostics allow early detection of pathogens by amplifying very small amounts of DNA
GEAC (Genetic Engineering Approval Committee) in India regulates research and release of GMOs and GM products
Biopiracy: unauthorised exploitation of biological resources — notable cases include neem, turmeric, and basmati rice
Patents on neem (pesticidal properties) and turmeric (wound healing) were challenged and revoked by India
Bioethics involves ethical questions about genetic manipulation, cloning, and modification of organisms

questions.question_text: Bt cotton is resistant to:
questions.explanation_correct: Bt cotton is a genetically modified crop that contains cry genes (Cry1Ac and Cry2Ab) from Bacillus thuringiensis. These genes encode Cry proteins that are toxic to cotton bollworms (Lepidopteran pests), making the cotton plants resistant to these insect pests.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bt cotton is not engineered for fungal resistance. It is not drought-resistant. Herbicide-resistant crops like Roundup Ready soybean use different genes. Bt specifically refers to insect resistance through Cry proteins.

questions.question_text:
The


 Cry proteins in Bt crops are produced by genes obtained from:
questions.explanation_correct: Cry proteins (crystal proteins) are encoded by cry genes from the soil bacterium Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt). During sporulation, this bacterium produces these proteins as inactive protoxins in crystalline form, which become toxic only when activated in the insect gut.
questions.explanation_incorrect: E. coli is used as a host organism in genetic engineering. Agrobacterium is used as a vector for gene transfer in plants. Thermus aquaticus is the source of Taq polymerase. Bacillus thuringiensis is the specific source of cry genes.

questions.question_text: Which Cry proteins are effective against cotton bollworms?
questions.explanation_correct: Cry1Ac and Cry2Ab are the specific Cry proteins effective against cotton bollworms (Lepidopteran pests like Helicoverpa armigera). Bt cotton in India predominantly uses these two proteins for protection against bollworm infestation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cry1Ab is used against corn borers, not cotton bollworms. Cry3Bb targets Coleopteran pests. Cry4A is effective against Dipteran insects (mosquitoes). Cry1Ac and Cry2Ab are the proteins specifically engineered into Bt cotton.

questions.question_text: A transgenic animal is one whose genome has been altered by:

options.text: Introduction of a foreign gene through genetic engineering

questions.explanation_correct: A transgenic animal is one that has had its genome deliberately altered by the introduction of a foreign gene (transgene) using genetic engineering techniques. The foreign gene integrates into the animal's genome and may be expressed in its cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Selective breeding is a conventional method, not genetic engineering. Natural mutations occur randomly and are not directed. Radiation exposure causes random mutations, not specific gene introduction. Transgenic animals are specifically created through deliberate gene insertion.

questions.question_text: The Cry protein exists as an inactive protoxin in Bacillus thuringiensis. It becomes active and toxic when:

options.text: Ingested by the insect larva and solubilised in the alkaline gut
It comes in contact with water

questions.explanation_correct: The Cry protein exists as an inactive protoxin (crystalline form) in the bacterium. When an insect larva ingests the Bt crop, the protoxin enters the alkaline gut where it is solubilised and processed by gut proteases into the active toxin form. The active toxin creates pores in the midgut epithelial cells, causing cell lysis and death of the larva.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sunlight does not activate the protoxin. Bacterial death alone does not activate it. Contact with water is not sufficient. The specific alkaline pH of the insect larval gut is required to convert the inactive protoxin into the active form.

questions.question_text: Bt toxin does not kill the bacterium Bacillus thuringiensis itself because:

options.text: The bacterium does not produce the toxin
The toxin exists in an inactive protoxin form inside the bacterium
The bacterium is resistant to all toxins
The toxin is secreted outside the bacterial cell

questions.explanation_correct: The Cry protein exists in an inactive crystalline protoxin form within the bacterium. It requires the alkaline pH and specific proteases of the insect gut to be activated. Since bacterial cells have a near-neutral pH, the protoxin remains inactive and harmless inside the bacterium.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The bacterium does produce the protein but in inactive form. It is not universally resistant to toxins. The protein is intracellular, not secreted. The key reason is that the protoxin is inactive at the neutral pH inside the bacterium.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an application of transgenic animals in biotechnology?

options.text: Studying gene regulation, testing vaccine safety, and producing biological products
Used only for racing and entertainment

questions.explanation_correct: Transgenic animals have multiple applications: studying normal physiology and gene regulation, studying disease mechanisms (models for human diseases like cancer), testing vaccine safety before clinical trials, producing biological products (like human proteins in milk), and testing toxicity of drugs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Transgenic animals have scientific and medical purposes, not just as pets. They are not created only for meat or entertainment. Their applications span research, medicine, and pharmaceutical production.

questions.question_text: RNA interference (RNAi) technology has been used to develop pest-resistant tobacco plants. In this technique:

options.text: A toxin gene from bacteria is introduced into the plant
Complementary dsRNA silences specific mRNA of the pest, preventing its survival
The plant is made resistant by increasing its cell wall thickness
Chemical pesticides are embedded into the plant genome

questions.explanation_correct: RNA interference (RNAi) involves introducing a gene that produces double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) complementary to the mRNA of a specific gene in the pest (e.g., nematode Meloidogyne incognita). When the pest feeds on the transgenic plant, the dsRNA silences (interferes with) the pest's essential gene, preventing its survival.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Introducing a bacterial toxin gene is the Bt approach, not RNAi. Increasing cell wall thickness is not RNAi. Chemical pesticides are not embedded in genomes. RNAi specifically involves gene silencing through complementary RNA.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Bt toxin is specific to certain insect groups and does not harm mammals.
Reason: The alkaline pH required for Cry protein activation is present in insect guts but not in mammalian stomachs, which have acidic pH.

Select the correct option:

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true but reason is false
Assertion is false but reason is true

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are true. Bt toxin is indeed specific to certain insect groups and safe for mammals. The reason correctly explains this — the Cry protoxin requires the alkaline pH of insect guts (pH 9-12) for activation. Mammalian stomachs are acidic (pH 1-3), so the protoxin cannot be activated and remains harmless.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion is correct — Bt toxin targets specific insect orders. The reason accurately explains the mechanism of specificity — pH-dependent activation. The acidic mammalian gut prevents activation, making Bt crops safe for human consumption.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly describes the mechanism of Bt toxin action in insect larvae?

options.text: Cry protein blocks the nervous system of the insect
Active Cry protein creates pores in the midgut epithelial cells, causing cell lysis and death
Cry protein prevents the insect from moulting
Cry protein degrades the insect's exoskeleton

questions.explanation_correct: The Cry protein, once activated by the alkaline gut pH and proteases, binds to specific receptors on the midgut epithelial cells and creates pores in the cell membrane. This leads to cell swelling, lysis, and eventually death of the insect larva due to disruption of the gut lining.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bt toxin does not act on the nervous system (that is the mechanism of some chemical insecticides). It does not prevent moulting or degrade the exoskeleton. Its mechanism is specifically through pore formation in gut epithelial cells.

questions.question_text: Nematode-resistant tobacco plants have been developed using:
questions.explanation_correct: Tobacco plants resistant to the root-knot nematode Meloidogyne incognita were developed using RNA interference (RNAi). A gene encoding dsRNA complementary to a specific nematode gene was introduced into the plant. When the nematode feeds on the plant, the dsRNA silences the nematode's gene, killing it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bt gene insertion provides resistance against insect pests, not nematodes. Somatic hybridisation combines traits of different species through protoplast fusion. Mutation breeding induces random mutations. RNAi is the specific technique used against nematodes in tobacco.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a purpose for creating transgenic animals?

options.text: Producing biological products in their milk
Increasing the speed of the animal for racing

questions.explanation_correct: Increasing speed for racing is not a purpose of creating transgenic animals. The legitimate purposes include: studying normal physiology and disease, testing vaccine safety, producing biological products (e.g., human alpha-lactalbumin in cow milk), and chemical safety testing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Disease models help understand human diseases. Vaccine safety testing ensures safety before human trials. Biological products like proteins can be produced in transgenic animal milk. Racing speed enhancement is not a biotechnological application.

questions.question_text: Cry1Ab protein is specifically toxic to:
questions.explanation_correct: Cry1Ab is a Cry protein that is specifically toxic to corn borers (Lepidopteran pests of maize). Different Cry proteins target different insect orders: Cry1 proteins target Lepidoptera, Cry3 proteins target Coleoptera, and Cry4 proteins target Diptera.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cotton bollworms are targeted by Cry1Ac and Cry2Ab. Mosquito larvae (Diptera) are targeted by Cry4 proteins. Beetles (Coleoptera) are targeted by Cry3 proteins. Cry1Ab specifically targets corn borers.

questions.question_text: Human insulin produced using recombinant DNA technology is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Humulin is the brand name for human insulin produced using recombinant DNA technology. The human insulin gene was introduced into E. coli, which then synthesises proinsulin. The proinsulin is processed to remove the C-peptide, yielding functional insulin with A and B chains linked by disulphide bonds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bovine insulin is extracted from cow pancreas. Porcine insulin is from pig pancreas. Proinsulin is the precursor form that needs processing. Humulin is the specific name for rDNA-produced human insulin.

questions.question_text: Gene therapy for ADA deficiency involves:

options.text: Replacing the entire genome of the patient
Introducing a functional ADA gene into the patient's lymphocytes
Removing the defective gene using restriction enzymes
Transplanting the patient's bone marrow into a healthy donor

questions.explanation_correct: Gene therapy for ADA (adenosine deaminase) deficiency involves collecting the patient's lymphocytes, introducing a functional ADA gene into them using a retroviral vector (ex vivo), growing the corrected cells in culture, and returning them to the patient. The functional gene produces the missing ADA enzyme.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The entire genome is not replaced; only one gene is introduced. Restriction enzymes cannot remove specific genes from a patient's cells. Bone marrow transplant is a separate treatment approach. The gene therapy specifically involves introducing a functional ADA gene into lymphocytes.

questions.question_text: ELISA stands for:
questions.explanation_correct: ELISA stands for Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay. It is a diagnostic technique based on the principle of antigen-antibody interaction. An enzyme linked to an antibody produces a colour change in the presence of the target antigen, allowing detection and quantification of pathogens or proteins.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options contain incorrect expansions. ELISA specifically involves enzyme-linked antibodies that bind to immobilised antigens (immunosorbent), producing a detectable colour change. It is a widely used diagnostic tool.

questions.question_text:
The


 first clinical gene therapy was given for the treatment of:
questions.explanation_correct: The first clinical gene therapy was performed in 1990 for a four-year-old girl with ADA (adenosine deaminase) deficiency. ADA deficiency causes severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) because the enzyme is needed for the functioning of the immune system.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gene therapy for cystic fibrosis, sickle cell anaemia, and haemophilia are being researched but ADA deficiency was the first condition to be treated with clinical gene therapy. It served as a proof-of-concept for this approach.

questions.question_text: In the production of human insulin using rDNA technology, the two polypeptide chains (A and B) are:

options.text: Produced separately in E. coli and then combined by forming disulphide bonds
Produced as a single functional insulin molecule directly
Chemically synthesised in the laboratory without using bacteria

questions.explanation_correct: In Eli Lilly's original approach, the A chain and B chain of human insulin were produced separately in two different E. coli cultures. The chains were then extracted, purified, and combined by creating disulphide bonds between them to form functional insulin. An alternative approach produces proinsulin which is then processed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: E. coli does not produce a directly functional insulin molecule in one step. The chains are not extracted from human cells (that would not be rDNA technology). They are not purely chemically synthesised. The biological production and subsequent assembly is the rDNA approach.

questions.question_text: ELISA is based on the principle of:
questions.explanation_correct: ELISA works on the principle of antigen-antibody interaction (immunological principle). The target antigen binds to a specific antibody that is linked to an enzyme. Upon adding the substrate, the enzyme produces a colour change proportional to the amount of antigen present, enabling detection and quantification.
questions.explanation_incorrect: DNA hybridisation is the basis of Southern blotting. DNA amplification is the principle of PCR. Gel electrophoresis separates molecules by size. ELISA is specifically based on the specificity of antigen-antibody binding.

questions.question_text: A patient is diagnosed with ADA deficiency and undergoes gene therapy. Why does the treatment need to be repeated periodically?

options.text: The gene therapy permanently cures the disease in one session
The corrected lymphocytes are not immortal and die, requiring fresh corrected cells
The patient develops immunity against the ADA enzyme
The functional gene mutates back to the defective form

questions.explanation_correct: Gene therapy for ADA deficiency involves introducing the ADA gene into the patient's lymphocytes. However, these corrected lymphocytes have a limited lifespan and eventually die. Since the gene is not permanently integrated into bone marrow stem cells (in the ex vivo approach), the treatment must be repeated.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gene therapy is not a permanent cure in this approach. The patient does not develop immunity against ADA. The gene does not mutate back. The temporary nature of corrected lymphocytes necessitates repeated treatments.

questions.question_text: PCR-based molecular diagnostics are preferred for early disease detection because:

options.text: They can only detect diseases at advanced stages
They can detect very small amounts of pathogen DNA even before symptoms appear
They are cheaper than all other methods
They do not require any specialised equipment

questions.explanation_correct: PCR can amplify extremely small amounts of pathogen DNA (even a single copy) to detectable levels. This enables early diagnosis of infections before clinical symptoms appear, when the pathogen load is still very low — conventional methods cannot detect such small amounts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: PCR excels at early detection, not late-stage. While cost-effectiveness varies, that is not the primary advantage. PCR does require specialised equipment (thermal cycler). The key advantage is the ability to detect minute amounts of pathogen DNA.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Gene therapy is a permanent cure for ADA deficiency when done using ex vivo lymphocyte correction.
Reason: Lymphocytes corrected with the ADA gene have a limited lifespan and need periodic replacement.

Select the correct option:

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is false but reason is true
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.explanation_correct: The assertion is false — gene therapy using ex vivo lymphocyte correction is NOT a permanent cure for ADA deficiency. The reason is true — corrected lymphocytes have a limited lifespan and die, requiring the patient to undergo repeated treatments. A permanent cure would require introducing the gene into bone marrow stem cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion incorrectly claims permanence. The reason correctly explains why it is not permanent — lymphocyte death necessitates repeated treatment. If the gene were introduced into self-renewing stem cells, a permanent cure might be possible.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about the production of human insulin by rDNA technology is correct?

options.text: Mature insulin consists of A, B, and C chains
Proinsulin contains an extra peptide called C-peptide which is removed during processing
E. coli naturally produces human insulin

questions.explanation_correct: Proinsulin contains three parts: the A chain, the B chain, and the C-peptide (connecting peptide). During processing, the C-peptide is removed by proteolytic cleavage, and the A and B chains are linked by disulphide bonds to form mature, functional insulin.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mature insulin consists of only A and B chains (not C). E. coli does not naturally produce insulin — it is engineered to do so. Insulin is not a single chain; it has two polypeptide chains (A and B) joined by disulphide bonds.

questions.question_text: Before the advent of rDNA technology, insulin for diabetic patients was extracted from:

options.text: Pancreas of slaughtered cattle and pigs

questions.explanation_correct: Before rDNA technology, insulin was extracted from the pancreas of slaughtered cattle (bovine insulin) and pigs (porcine insulin). However, this animal-derived insulin sometimes caused allergic reactions in some patients due to slight differences in amino acid sequences from human insulin.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Human liver cells do not produce insulin. Bacteria do not naturally produce insulin. Plants do not produce insulin. Only animal pancreatic extracts were used before recombinant technology.

questions.question_text: ADA deficiency affects the immune system because:

options.text: ADA enzyme is needed for the digestion of food
ADA is crucial for the functioning of T-lymphocytes; its deficiency causes SCID
ADA is a hormone that activates white blood cells

questions.explanation_correct: Adenosine deaminase (ADA) is an enzyme essential for purine metabolism. Its deficiency leads to accumulation of toxic metabolites (deoxyadenosine) that are particularly harmful to T-lymphocytes, causing severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) where the immune system is severely compromised.
questions.explanation_incorrect: ADA is not involved in food digestion. ADA does not produce antibodies; it is a metabolic enzyme. ADA is an enzyme, not a hormone. Its deficiency specifically damages T-lymphocytes, leading to immunodeficiency.

questions.question_text: Gene therapy involves:

options.text: Replacing all defective genes in every cell of the body
Correction of a genetic defect by delivering a normal functional gene into the patient's cells
Removing all genes from the patient's cells
Transplanting genes from one species to another for food production

questions.explanation_correct: Gene therapy is the correction of a genetic disorder by delivering a normal, functional copy of the gene into the patient's cells to compensate for the non-functional or defective gene. It may involve ex vivo (cells removed, corrected, returned) or in vivo (direct gene delivery) approaches.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It does not replace all genes in every cell. Genes are not removed from cells. Gene therapy is specifically for treating genetic diseases in humans, not for food production. The approach is to supplement with a functional gene, not remove defective ones.

questions.question_text: Which molecular diagnostic technique would be most suitable for confirming HIV infection by detecting viral proteins?
questions.explanation_correct: ELISA is the most suitable technique for detecting HIV viral proteins (antigens) or antibodies against HIV in the patient's blood. It uses the antigen-antibody interaction principle with an enzyme-linked detection system. It is the standard screening test for HIV.
questions.explanation_incorrect: PCR detects viral nucleic acid (DNA/RNA), not proteins. Gel electrophoresis separates molecules by size but is not a diagnostic test. Southern blotting detects specific DNA sequences. ELISA is specifically designed to detect proteins (antigens/antibodies).

questions.question_text: GEAC in India stands for:
questions.explanation_correct: GEAC stands for Genetic Engineering Approval Committee. It is the regulatory body in India that makes decisions regarding the validity of GM research and the safety of introducing GM organisms for public services. It operates under the Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect expansions. GEAC specifically stands for Genetic Engineering Approval Committee and is the apex regulatory body for GMOs in India.

questions.question_text: Biopiracy refers to:

options.text: Stealing laboratory equipment from biotech companies
Unauthorised use of bio-resources and traditional knowledge by organisations without proper authorisation or compensation

questions.explanation_correct: Biopiracy is the exploitation of biological resources and associated traditional knowledge of developing countries by multinational companies and organisations without proper authorisation, benefit-sharing, or compensation to the countries and communities of origin.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Biopiracy is not about stealing equipment, textbooks, or animal trade. It specifically refers to the unauthorised commercial exploitation of genetic resources and indigenous knowledge, often through patents.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a well-known case of biopiracy involving India?

options.text: Patenting of penicillin by a US company
Patenting of turmeric for its wound-healing properties by a US patent office

questions.explanation_correct: A well-known case of biopiracy was the granting of a US patent for the use of turmeric in wound healing. India challenged this patent, providing evidence that turmeric's medicinal properties had been documented in ancient Indian texts for centuries. The patent was eventually revoked.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Penicillin was discovered in the UK, not related to Indian biopiracy. Taq polymerase was discovered in the US. Bt toxin gene patents are a different issue. The turmeric patent case is a classic example of biopiracy against India's traditional knowledge.

questions.question_text: Bioethics deals with:

options.text: Only the financial aspects of biotechnology
Ethical, moral, and social issues arising from biotechnology and genetic manipulation

questions.explanation_correct: Bioethics is a branch of ethics that deals with the moral, social, and philosophical questions arising from biological and medical research, including genetic engineering, cloning, stem cell research, and the release of GMOs. It guides responsible conduct in biotechnology.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bioethics is not about finances, marketing, or just lab safety. It encompasses broader ethical questions about human genetic modification, organism manipulation, environmental impact of GMOs, and the moral boundaries of biotechnology.

questions.question_text: India successfully challenged the patent on neem granted to a foreign company because:

options.text: India provided evidence that neem's properties were part of traditional Indian knowledge for centuries
The company did not pay taxes in India

questions.explanation_correct: India challenged the patent on neem (granted to a US company for its pesticidal properties) by providing extensive documentation proving that neem's medicinal and pesticidal properties had been known and used in Indian traditional knowledge systems for centuries. This prior art invalidated the patent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Neem is not endangered. Neem is not toxic or unsafe. Tax issues were not the basis of the challenge. The key argument was prior art — India demonstrated that the 'invention' was actually traditional knowledge long documented in Indian texts.

questions.question_text:
The




 role of GEAC in India includes:

options.text: Only promoting the sale of GM crops
Regulating GM research and deciding the safety of introducing GMOs for public use

questions.explanation_correct: GEAC regulates the research, development, and release of genetically modified organisms in India. It evaluates the safety of GM products for human consumption and environmental impact, and grants or denies approval for field trials and commercial release of GMOs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: GEAC does not merely promote GM crop sales. It does not ban all GMOs — it evaluates each case. It is not a funding body. GEAC's primary role is regulatory — evaluating safety and granting/denying approval for GMOs.

questions.question_text: Which of the following bio-resources from India has NOT been subject to biopiracy disputes?
questions.explanation_correct: Taq polymerase was isolated from Thermus aquaticus found in hot springs in Yellowstone National Park, USA. It is not an Indian bio-resource and has not been subject to biopiracy disputes involving India. Neem, turmeric, and basmati rice are all Indian bio-resources that were involved in biopiracy cases.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Neem was patented for pesticidal properties by a foreign company. Turmeric was patented for wound healing. Basmati rice was patented by a US company (RiceTec). All three involved biopiracy of Indian resources. Taq polymerase is unrelated to Indian biopiracy.

questions.question_text: A major concern regarding the release of genetically modified organisms into the environment is:

options.text: GMOs always cause cancer in humans
Potential transfer of transgenes to wild relatives, creating 'superweeds'
GMOs cannot survive outside the laboratory

questions.explanation_correct: A major biosafety concern is gene flow — the potential transfer of transgenes (such as herbicide resistance) from GM crops to related wild species through cross-pollination. This could create 'superweeds' that are resistant to herbicides, disrupting natural ecosystems.
questions.explanation_incorrect: GMOs do not always cause cancer — this is not scientifically established. GMOs can survive outside laboratories. GMOs do not always improve the environment. The real concern is unintended gene transfer to wild species and its ecological consequences.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: India challenged and got the US patent on basmati rice revoked.
Reason: Basmati rice is a traditional Indian variety and its properties were already known and documented in India.

Select the correct option:

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true but reason is false
Both assertion and reason are true; India challenged the basmati patent, and it was partially amended

questions.explanation_correct: India did challenge the US patent on basmati rice (granted to RiceTec Inc., a Texas-based company). However, the patent was not fully revoked but was significantly narrowed/amended. The reason is true — basmati is a traditional Indian variety grown in the Indo-Gangetic plains for centuries. India's challenge was based on this prior knowledge.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion is partially true — India challenged the patent but it was amended rather than completely revoked. The reason is true. The basmati case is one of the most well-known biopiracy cases involving India.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a valid concern about genetically modified organisms?

options.text: Transfer of allergen genes into food crops
Potential harm to non-target organisms in the ecosystem
GMOs may reduce biodiversity by displacing native species
All GM foods are proven to cause immediate health hazards

questions.explanation_correct: The statement that all GM foods cause immediate health hazards is incorrect and not a scientifically valid concern. While safety testing is important, no blanket statement about all GM foods being harmful is supported by evidence. The other options (allergen transfer, non-target effects, biodiversity loss) are legitimate scientific concerns.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Allergen gene transfer is a valid concern in GM crop development. Harm to non-target organisms (like monarch butterflies from Bt pollen) is a documented concern. Biodiversity reduction is a genuine ecological concern. The blanket claim about immediate health hazards is not scientifically supported.

questions.question_text:
The







Indian government established the 'Traditional Knowledge Digital Library' (TKDL) primarily to:

options.text: Promote the export of traditional medicines
Prevent biopiracy by documenting India's traditional knowledge as prior art
Sell traditional knowledge to multinational companies
Replace modern medicine with traditional practices

questions.explanation_correct: The Traditional Knowledge Digital Library (TKDL) was created by the Indian government to document India's traditional knowledge (from Ayurveda, Unani, Siddha, and Yoga) in a format accessible to patent examiners worldwide. This serves as prior art to prevent the granting of illegitimate patents — a key strategy against biopiracy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: TKDL is not for promoting exports or selling knowledge. It is not meant to replace modern medicine. Its primary purpose is to prevent biopiracy by establishing documented prior art that patent offices can reference when evaluating patent applications.

questions.question_text: Flavr Savr tomato was the first commercially grown GM food crop. It was engineered for:
questions.explanation_correct: Flavr Savr tomato was engineered for delayed fruit ripening using antisense RNA technology. The antisense gene blocks the production of the enzyme polygalacturonase, which is responsible for softening the fruit during ripening. This extended the shelf life of the tomato.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Insect resistance uses Bt genes. Increased vitamin content is biofortification. Herbicide tolerance uses genes like Roundup Ready. Flavr Savr was specifically about delaying ripening for longer shelf life.

questions.question_text: Herbicide-tolerant GM crops are useful to farmers because:

options.text: Farmers can spray herbicides to kill weeds without damaging the crop
They do not require any weeding
They kill all insects in the field

questions.explanation_correct: Herbicide-tolerant GM crops (like Roundup Ready soybean) carry a gene that makes them resistant to a specific herbicide (glyphosate). Farmers can spray the herbicide on the entire field to kill weeds without harming the crop, making weed management efficient.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The crops do not produce herbicides. Weeds still grow but can be controlled with herbicide spraying. Herbicide tolerance is not related to insect killing. The benefit is that herbicide application kills weeds but the crop survives.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a correct application of molecular diagnostics?

options.text: PCR for detecting pathogen DNA in early infection
Gene therapy for correcting genetic disorders

questions.explanation_correct: Gene therapy is a treatment approach, not a diagnostic technique. Molecular diagnostics include techniques like ELISA and PCR that detect disease-causing agents or their markers. Gene therapy corrects genetic defects and belongs to the therapeutic category, not diagnostics.
questions.explanation_incorrect: ELISA for HIV antibodies is a standard diagnostic application. PCR for pathogen DNA is used in early detection. ELISA can detect toxins. Gene therapy is the only non-diagnostic option — it is a therapeutic intervention.

questions.question_text:
In Bt cotton, the


 cry gene has been modified before inserting into plants. Why?

options.text: The bacterial cry gene has GATC sequences that are cut by restriction enzymes
Bacterial codon usage differs from plant codon usage, so the gene is optimised for expression in plants
The gene is too small to be detected
The original gene produces a toxin harmful to plants

questions.explanation_correct: The cry gene from Bacillus thuringiensis needs to be modified (codon-optimised) before insertion into plants because bacterial codon usage differs from plant codon usage. The modified gene ensures efficient transcription and translation in plant cells, producing adequate levels of Cry protein.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Restriction enzyme sites are not the primary issue. The gene size is adequate. The Cry protein is not harmful to plants. The main reason for modification is to match plant codon preferences for effective gene expression.

questions.question_text: In the context of molecular diagnostics, a 'probe' refers to:

options.text: A labelled single-stranded DNA or RNA that hybridises with a complementary sequence

questions.explanation_correct: In molecular diagnostics, a probe is a short, labelled (radioactively or with a fluorescent dye) single-stranded DNA or RNA molecule that can hybridise (base-pair) with a complementary DNA/RNA sequence. Probes are used to detect specific genes or pathogens in diagnostic assays.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A probe in molecular biology is not a surgical instrument. It is not a restriction enzyme or culture medium. It is specifically a labelled nucleic acid sequence used for detecting complementary sequences through hybridisation.

questions.question_text: Which international agreement addresses the safe transfer, handling, and use of GMOs?
questions.explanation_correct: The Cartagena Protocol on Biosafety (under the Convention on Biological Diversity) addresses the safe transfer, handling, and use of living modified organisms (LMOs/GMOs) resulting from modern biotechnology that may have adverse effects on biodiversity and human health.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Kyoto Protocol deals with greenhouse gas emissions. The Montreal Protocol addresses ozone-depleting substances. The Paris Agreement is about climate change mitigation. The Cartagena Protocol is specifically about biosafety of GMOs.

questions.question_text: A transgenic cow, Rosie, produced human protein-enriched milk. The protein was:
questions.explanation_correct: Rosie was the first transgenic cow that produced human protein-enriched milk. Her milk contained human alpha-lactalbumin, which is nutritionally more balanced for human babies than normal cow milk. This was achieved by introducing the human alpha-lactalbumin gene into the cow.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Human insulin is produced in E. coli, not in cow milk. Haemoglobin is a blood protein not produced in milk. Growth hormone production in transgenic animals uses different approaches. Rosie specifically produced human alpha-lactalbumin in her milk.

questions.question_text: Before rDNA insulin was available, animal insulin sometimes caused allergic reactions in patients because:

options.text: Animal insulin was contaminated with bacteria
The amino acid sequence of animal insulin differs slightly from human insulin
Patients were allergic to all proteins

questions.explanation_correct: Bovine (cattle) and porcine (pig) insulin differ slightly in amino acid sequence from human insulin. These differences, though small, were sufficient to trigger immune responses (allergic reactions) in some patients because the immune system recognised the foreign amino acids as non-self.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The insulin was purified and not contaminated with bacteria. Concentration was not the issue. Not all patients are allergic to all proteins. The specific cause was the slight amino acid differences between animal and human insulin sequences.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements best describes the concern of 'genetic pollution'?

options.text: Industrial pollution affecting the genes of factory workers
Unintended spread of transgenes from GM crops to wild relatives or non-GM crops
Chemical contamination of DNA in laboratory experiments
Genetic mutations caused by air pollution

questions.explanation_correct: Genetic pollution refers to the unintended and uncontrolled spread of transgenes from genetically modified organisms to wild species or non-GM crop varieties through cross-pollination or horizontal gene transfer. This could alter the genetic makeup of natural populations irreversibly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is not about industrial pollution affecting workers. It is not about laboratory DNA contamination. It is not about mutation from air pollution. Genetic pollution specifically concerns transgene escape from GM organisms to the wild.

questions.question_text: Which of the following crops has been genetically modified for commercial cultivation in India?
questions.explanation_correct: Bt cotton is the only genetically modified crop approved for commercial cultivation in India (since 2002). It contains Cry genes for resistance against cotton bollworms. Bt brinjal was approved but put on an indefinite moratorium. Golden rice and Roundup Ready soybean are not commercially grown in India.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bt brinjal was put on moratorium in 2010 and is not commercially cultivated. Golden rice has not been approved for cultivation in India. Roundup Ready soybean is not grown commercially in India. Bt cotton remains the sole commercially grown GM crop in India.

questions.question_text: Bioethical concerns regarding human cloning include:

options.text: Only the cost of the procedure
Questions about individuality, dignity, and potential for exploitation
Only the technical difficulty of the process

questions.explanation_correct: Bioethical concerns about human cloning encompass deep questions about human individuality and identity, human dignity, the potential for exploitation and commodification of human life, psychological impacts on cloned individuals, and the moral status of cloned embryos.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cost is a practical concern but not the primary ethical issue. Technical difficulty is a scientific challenge, not an ethical concern. Health improvement is a potential benefit, not a concern. The key bioethical issues revolve around dignity, identity, and exploitation.

questions.question_text:
Match the following biotechnology applications with their descriptions:

Column I: (a) Humulin, (b) Gene therapy, (c) ELISA, (d) PCR
Column II: (i) DNA amplification technique, (ii) Antigen-antibody based diagnostic, (iii) rDNA-produced human insulin, (iv) Correction of genetic defects
questions.explanation_correct: Humulin is rDNA-produced human insulin (a-iii). Gene therapy corrects genetic defects by introducing functional genes (b-iv). ELISA is a diagnostic technique based on antigen-antibody interaction (c-ii). PCR is a DNA amplification technique (d-i).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Each biotechnology application has a specific definition. Humulin is insulin produced by rDNA technology. Gene therapy addresses genetic disorders. ELISA is an immunological diagnostic. PCR amplifies DNA. Only option A correctly matches all four.
